moves.1. d4 d5 2. c4 c6 3. e3 Nf6 4. Nc3 Bf5 5: Maybe I should've played h6 in case of Nh4.
moves.7. Ne5: Here's where it gets interesting, as we are leaving the opening lines. White begins to get aggressive.
moves.7... Nxe5 8. dxe5 Ne4 9. Bd2 Nxd2 10. Qx: If I take the pawn right away on e5, I'd be faced with an immediate checkmate: 14. Qd7#
moves.13... Be7: At least now my king has an escape square on f8 for the mate threat.
moves.14. Bg2 Rd8 15. Qc2 Rxd1+ 16. Rxd1 Qxe5: If I would have played this on move 14, I might have saved my e4 pawn, but I guess if I didn't wait I'd be losing my b pawn instead to Qd7+.
moves.18. f4 Qc5 19. Qd3 O-O 20. f5 Rd8: Again, I repeat the process of distroying White's battery. It looks remarkedly similar to move 14.
moves.23... exf5: I did not want to let my e pawn go to waste if he took on g6 first.
moves.24. gxf5 Qg3: ...And now I fork his e and h pawns.
moves.25. fxg6 hxg6 26. Qg2 Qxe3: I now have an advantage, but one must be very cautious when playing queen endgames.
moves.27. Kc2 Qd4: Now I had to take care of the threat against my g pawn.
moves.30. Qe2 Qb6+: Here was where my opponent sighed in regret. I win the b pawn. Ka3 leads to Be7+ and later Qb4#
moves.31. Kc2 Qxb2+ 32. Kd1: Note that Kd3 leads to mate on c3. I thought a moment before exchanging queens, to see if I could win more material later, but I usually prefer simplicity when I have a big advantage.
I do not want the white king in my territory, obviously.
moves.38. Ke3 b6 39. Kf4 g5+ 40. Kg3 Ke5 41. h: White is willing to sacrifice a pawn to separate my paired passed pawns.
moves.41... gxh4+ 42. Kh3 Kf4: My king is swift to advance.
moves.43. Bh5 Ke3 44. Kg2 f4 45. Bg4 Bf6 46. B: I believe this sacrifice was the only way to get my other pawn to advance.
moves.47. Kxh3 f3 48. Kg3 Bh4+: If he takes it, I promote.
moves.49. Kh3 Be1 50. Kh2 f2 51. Kg2 Kd3 52. B: A better move would have been a6.
moves.54. Bb5 Ka5 55. Bc6 Kb4: Better would have been, again, a6. But we will return to a similar position later.
moves.56. Bb5: I was dissapointed in the fact that I might have reached a draw despite my clear advantage, but I wasn't about to give up. All the other boards were finished, the score  2-2, and this game would decide the league champion. We needed a win.
moves.56... Kb3 57. Kf3: From this point on the notation is only approximate. I was running low on time.
moves.57... Kc3: I was too dumb to notice, on two occasions, that I could have promoted this turn. Maybe he went to f1 that first time.
moves.58. Ke2: Note that just because a pawn is on the 7th, protected by a bishop, doesn't mean it'll promote. White's king is free to roam about the e2, f1, and g2 squares.
moves.58... Kd4 59. Kf3: This was that 2nd dumb occasion. White's bishop would have to oscillate between a6 and b5 or my king would get to e2 and I would promote. Neither of us realized it, though.
moves.59... Kc3 60. Ke2 Kb4: Seeing as this apparently failed, I decided to go back.
moves.61. Kf1 Ka5 62. Bc6 a6 63. Bb7: And then I found the move...
moves.63... b5: If I would have taken the a pawn, the position would be hopelessly drawn. Although I was at first skeptical about this move, I finally realized its importance. White must now take the pawn on b5 or face a deadly threat of promotion, but afterward the a6 pawn will recapture and be saved. Black's position is clearly won.
moves.64. Bxa6 bxa4 65. Bb5 a3:
White resigns with less than 3 minutes on the clock for both of us. This was truly a long and exciting game. With this win, Kamiak won the WESCO league by a single point*, and for the first time ever. I hope you enjoyed viewing this as much as I enjoyed sharing it.

*It was actually 1.5 points, since Stanwood had to make up a match against Monroe, for which we expected them to win 5-0 (no offence to Monroe), but instead they went 4.5-0.5.
